abstract.p: Zebrafish, in contrast to mammals, regenerate neurons after spinal cord injury, but little is known about the control mechanisms of this process. Here we show that microglia are the main cell type to express the evolutionarily conserved signalling molecule sema4ab in the injury site. Deletion of sema4ab doubles the number of newly generated progenitor cells and neurons after spinal injury. Using scRNAseq of all lesion site cell types after gene disruption, we find that sema4ab supports the microglial activation state and promotes interactions with fibroblasts and neural progenitor cells. Mechanistically, sema4ab signals through plxn1a/b receptors on spinal progenitors and attenuates expression of the neurogenesis-promoting cytokine tgfb3 in fibroblasts. Hence, microglia regulate neurogenesis via sema4ab in successful spinal cord regeneration in zebrafish, which may be one of the mechanisms preventing regenerative neurogenesis in the mammalian spinal cord.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Mammals, including humans, fail to regenerate neurons lost to protracted secondary cell death around a spinal injury site (Dusart & Schwab, 1994; Liu et al, 1997). Spinal progenitor cells can generate new neurons in a conducive environment and can even be re-programmed in vivo to produce oligodendrocytes, but not neurons (Llorens-Bobadilla et al, 2020; Shihabuddin et al, 2000; Stenudd et al, 2022). The environment in a spinal injury site consists of immune cells, such as invading blood-derived macrophages (BDMs) and tissue-resident microglia, astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and fibroblasts. Interactions of these cell types result in an inhibitory environment for regenerative neurogenesis in which prolonged inflammation, as well as fibrotic and astrocytic scarring predominates (Anderson et al, 2016; Dias et al, 2018; Francos-Quijorna et al, 2022; Griffin & Bradke, 2020; Tran et al, 2018).

In contrast to mammals, zebrafish functionally regenerate their spinal cord at the adult and larval stage (Becker et al, 2004; Chang et al, 2021; Mokalled et al, 2016; Ohnmacht et al, 2016; Vandestadt et al, 2021). This includes regeneration of new neurons from resident progenitors (Briona & Dorsky, 2014; Briona et al, 2015; Huang et al, 2021; Ohnmacht et al., 2016; Reimer et al, 2008). In zebrafish, these progenitor cells are termed ependymo-radial glial cells (ERGs), by virtue of their combination of ependymal and astroglial features (Becker & Becker, 2015).

A large number of signalling molecules from various cellular sources have been discovered that promote regenerative neurogenesis and axon growth in the zebrafish model (Becker & Becker, 2022). Importantly, regenerative neurogenesis avoids over-proliferation, which may be encountered when transplanting neural progenitor cells to a spinal lesion (Sharp et al, 2014), or exhaustion of the progenitor pool, for example observed in a stroke model in mice (Carlen et al, 2009). Hence production of new neurons must be precisely regulated in zebrafish.

Microglia signal in the lesion via cytokines and are therefore in a key position to provide such regulation. In the injured telencephalon, microglia have been found to promote regenerative neurogenesis (Kyritsis et al, 2012). However, after a spinal cord injury, microglial cells proliferate (Becker & Becker, 2001), but lack expression of the neurogenesis-promoting cytokine tnfa, found in BDMs (Cavone et al, 2021; Tsarouchas et al, 2018).

Microglia likely interact with a number of other regeneration-relevant cell types that also influence regenerative neurogenesis. For example, ERGs and astrocyte-like cells produce a range of regeneration-promoting growth factors in central nervous system (CNS) injuries in zebrafish (Cigliola et al, 2023; Goldshmit et al, 2012; Mokalled et al., 2016) and fibroblasts that invade a spinal lesion site promote regeneration by producing favourable extracellular matrix components for axonal regeneration (Kolb et al, 2023; Tsata et al, 2021; Wehner et al, 2017).

To understand how microglia influence the signalling landscape in the injury site and regenerative neurogenesis, we analysed the role of the conserved signalling molecule Semaphorin 4A (Sema4A). Sema4a that is mainly expressed by microglia and BDMs and can change their activation state (Leitner et al, 2015; Meda et al, 2012). Sema4a has been shown to promote a pro-fibrotic phenotype in fibroblasts in vitro, suggesting possible interactions with fibroblasts (Carvalheiro et al, 2019). Knock out of the principal Sema4A receptors Plexin B1 and B2 impairs neurogenesis in the developing mouse brain (Daviaud et al, 2016), suggesting microglia to progenitor cell communication.

Here, we find that a zebrafish orthologue of Sema4A, semaphorin4ab (sema4ab), in microglia maintains their activation state and attenuates neural progenitor proliferation. Sema4ab likely acts directly on ERGs via plxnb1a/b and indirectly, by reducing the production of the pro-neurogenic factor tgfb3 in fibroblasts. Hence, sema4ab+ microglia regulate regenerative neurogenesis in the regeneration-permissive cellular environment of the zebrafish spinal cord.

sec.title: scRNAseq indicates changes in microglia signalling interactions in the absence of sema4ab that increase neurogenesis
sec.p: To better understand possible microglia/ERG communication in the complex lesion site environment, we decided to mutagenize the potential microglia activation factor sema4ab and analyse the consequences simultaneously for all relevant cell types by using scRNAseq. After a complete spinal lesion at 3 days post-fertilization (dpf), lesion-induced neurogenesis peaks at 24 hours post-lesion (hpl) in larval zebrafish; axons have regrown over the lesion site and swimming function is largely recovered by 48 hpl (Ohnmacht et al., 2016; Wehner et al., 2017). Thus, major regenerative processes occur within 48 hpl.

We injected larvae with highly-active CrRNAs (haCRs) that lead to mutagenesis of the targeted site in nearly all somatic cells, allowing phenotype analysis already in haCR-injected somatic mutants for sema4ab (Keatinge et al, 2021). We generated scRNAseq profiles of lesion site tissue from 50 control gRNA-injected and 50 sema4ab haCR-injected larvae at 24 hpl, the peak of regenerative neurogenesis (Ohnmacht et al., 2016) (Fig. 1A).

Our scRNAseq experiments yielded 11788 cells for the control gRNA-injected sample (gControl), 11621 cells for sample 1 (gSema4abR1), and 11330 cells for sample 2 (gSema4abR2) of two technical repeats of sema4ab haCR-injected larvae after quality control. (Suppl. Tables 1, 2). The haCR manipulation of sema4ab was highly penetrant, as no intact reads of the targeted site could be retrieved, contrary to controls (151 correct reads in controls; 4 reads, none of which were correct, in sema4ab haCR-injected larvae; Suppl. Table 3, see Suppl. Table 4 for example reads). Moreover, principal component analysis indicated that the two technical repeats of the sema4ab haCR treated condition were very closely related and more distant from the control sample (Suppl. Fig. 1A).

Unsupervised clustering and annotation revealed 44 distinct cell clusters that fell into 15 major cell categories (Fig. 1B,C). Fibroblast-like cells constituted the majority of all cells (21.13 %), consisting of 7 clusters, followed by neural cells (14.86%), consisting of ERGs, oligodendrocytes and 4 neuronal clusters, red blood cells (13.54 %), consisting of three clusters, muscle cells (13.54 %), consisting of 5 clusters, and immune cells (11.63 %), consisting of 4 BDM/microglia and 2 neutrophil clusters. Hence, all major cell types expected from histology were represented in the samples, allowing for comprehensive analyses of cell interactions in the lesioned larval zebrafish spinal cord.

High and selective expression of sema4ab was found in a cluster of BDM/microglia (Fig. 1D), cluster MM #1. Using microglia marker apoeb (Peri & Nusslein-Volhard, 2008) and a marker set from adult zebrafish brain (Zambusi et al, 2022) we found that MM#1 and MM#2 expressed higher levels of microglial marker genes, compared to MM#3 and MM#4, which expressed more BDM-related genes. Population MM#2, in contrast to population MM#1, expressed proliferation markers, but otherwise marker expression was very similar between the two populations (Fig. 1E). Therefore, MM#2 likely is a proliferative sub-group of microglia and together with population MM#1 represent microglia. Hence, microglia is the main cell type expressing sema4ab in the injury site.

To determine gene expression changes in microglia in the absence of sema4ab function, we used GOstats for KEGG analysis (Falcon & Gentleman, 2007) on microglia cluster MM#1. This indicated changes in activation pathways, namely RIG-I-like receptor signalling (Yoneyama et al, 2024), Toll-like receptor signalling pathways (Alhamdan et al, 2024) and NOD-like receptor signalling (Almeida-da-Silva et al, 2023) (Fig. 1F). Most of the indicator genes were under-represented in the sample in which sema4ab was disrupted compared to the control sample (20 of 21 genes for RIG-I-pathway, 29 of 32 for Toll-like receptor pathway; 16 of 17 genes for NOD-like receptor signalling; Suppl. Data file 1), suggesting reduced activation of microglia in the absence of sema4ab.

Analysis of the top down-regulated genes in MM#1 confirms this result (Table 1). For example, one of the most underrepresented genes, lyz (5.91-fold down), is related to a pro-inflammatory state (Barros et al., 2015; MacParland et al., 2018). Similarly, grn1 (6.87-fold down), is linked to a pro-inflammatory state and cytokine production (Horinokita et al., 2019).

Reduced activation of microglia likely influences a number of cell types in the injury site. Comparing cell numbers between samples indicated no major changes in cell type representation resulting from sema4ab disruption (Suppl. Fig. 1B), with the possible exception of peridermis cluster 2 (PD#2), which showed a ~50 % reduction in cell number (Suppl. Fig. 1C). However, we observed alterations in gene expression. The highest changes in gene expression (> 300 differentially expressed genes) were present in microglia (MM#1, MM#2), neutrophils (NP#1), neurons (NN#2), fibroblasts (FB#1, FB#2, FB#3, FB#5), muscle (MC#1), peridermal cells (PD#1, PD#2), as well as in keratinocytes (KC#1, KC#2) and red blood cells (RB#1) (Suppl. Fig. 1D). Interestingly, most clusters showed reduced gene expression, with the exception of one neuronal cluster NN#2, which showed increased gene expression. This indicates changes in gene expression across many cell types when sema4ab is disrupted in microglia.

To get a comprehensive view of how cell types could be affected by changes in microglia, we used CellChat, which evaluates cell interactions based on known ligand-receptor interactions in scRNAseq data (Jin et al, 2021). An analysis of the outgoing interactions of microglia indicated potentially altered signal/receptor interactions with all identified cell cluster, including ERGs (black circle) and fibroblasts (red line), but also with themselves and their proliferative version MM#2 (square) (Fig. 1G). Most of these signal/ligand interactions were diminished when sema4ab was disrupted. To determine potential direct signalling from microglia to ERGs, we analysed potentially altered signal/receptor interactions between microglia and ERGs. That indicated reduced interactions of sema4ab with plxnb1a, plxnb1b and plxn2a (Fig. 1H). Hence, scRNAseq predicts microglia to directly signal to ERGs using Sema4ab to Plexin receptors.

Of note, fibroblasts have pivotal functions in successful spinal cord regeneration in zebrafish (Tsata & Wehner, 2021), and all 7 clusters of fibroblasts show reduced incoming signals from microglia, when sema4ab is disrupted. Affected signal/receptor interactions included cytokine signalling (e.g. tnfb, tgfb1b), among other pathways (Suppl. Fig. 1E). In addition, KEGG analysis for the three fibroblast populations that showed highest levels of differentially expressed genes after sema4ab disruption (FB#1, FB#2, FB#3) indicated ECM-receptor interactions, TGF-beta signalling, and adherens junction pathways as changed (Fig. 1I). This data suggests that signalling and ECM-related functions were changed in fibroblasts when sema4ab was disrupted. Hence, scRNA-seq indicates multiple simultaneous signalling events of sema4ab+ microglia with other non-neural lesion cells, such as fibroblasts, that likely condition the lesion environment.

To determine whether such changed interactions influence regenerative neurogenesis, we analysed changes in proliferation and in gene expression related to neuronal differentiation in ERGs. Using the “Cell-Cycling Scoring and Regression” analysis code in Seurat (Satija et al, 2015) we calculated the proportion of cells in different cells cycle phases. We found a substantial increase in cells in G2/M phase in sema4ab-injected larvae (gControl: 16%, gSema4ab: 28%) (Fig. 1J). Additionally, a comparison of neuronal differentiation markers (neurog1, neurod1, ascl1a) and motor neuron cell fate marker mnx1, showed increased expression in ERGs in the absence of sema4ab function (Fig. 1K). This is consistent with enhanced progenitor proliferation and neurogenesis. Overall, scRNA-seq suggests a scenario, in which direct signalling via sema4a from microglial cells to spinal progenitors, as well as via other cell types, attenuates neurogenesis.

sec.title: Sema4ab is expressed mainly in microglia during regeneration
sec.p: To verify observations from scRNA-seq in vivo, we first analysed sema4ab expression during regeneration in whole-mounted larvae by multiplexed hybridization chain reaction fluorescence in situ hybridization (HCR-FISH) in combination with immune cell type-specific transgenic and HCR-FISH markers. Microglia were identified in mpeg:mCherry transgenic fish, in which mCherry is expressed under the mpeg1.1 promoter (Ellett et al, 2011), and by additional expression of apoeb (mpeg:mCherry+/apoeb+). Putative BDMs were mpeg:mCherry+/apoeb-. Neutrophils were detected in mpx:GFP transgenic fish, in which GFP is expressed under the mpx promoter (Renshaw et al, 2006).

In uninjured three-day-old larvae, hardly any sema4ab+ cells were detectable, consistent with expression in injury-reactive immune cells. In contrast, at 6 hpl, numbers of sema4ab+ cells were strongly increased in the lesion site and remained high to at least 48 hpl (Fig. 2A-C; see Suppl. Fig. 2A for method control).

Co-labelling experiments at 24 hpl indicated that the majority of sema4ab+ cells were microglia (60.6 %, sema4ab+; mpeg1:GFP+, apoeb+). 17.7 % were putative BDMs (sema4ab+, mpeg1:GFP+, apoeb-), and 12.7% were unidentified (sema4ab+ only; Fig. 2D-G). Co-labelling of sema4ab with mpx:GFP expressing neutrophils indicated that 16 % of sema4ab+ cells were neutrophils at 6 hpl and at 24 hpl (Suppl. Fig. 2B-D), indicating that the few sema4ab+ cells not labelled by mpeg:mCherry were likely mostly neutrophils. In summary, a spinal lesion induced the presence of sema4ab+ immune cells, with few if any non-immune cells expressing the gene in the lesion site. The vast majority of sema4ab+ immune cells were microglial cells, confirming scRNAseq results.

sec.title: Sema4ab disruption increases regenerative neurogenesis
sec.p: For a loss-of-function analysis of sema4ab in regenerative neurogenesis, we targeted sema4ab in somatic mutants and generated a stable germline mutant from haCR-injected fish. The germline mutant introduced a 14 bp insertion in exon 6, leading to a premature stop codon, which is predicted to lead to a truncated protein lacking functionally important domains, such as sema superfamily domains, plexin repeat domains and the intracellular part, containing a sema4F domain (Suppl. Fig.3A). Somatic mutants (Suppl. Fig. 3B-C) showed no differences in growth compared to control gRNA injected larvae, as measured by body length (Suppl. Fig. 3D), notochord thickness (Suppl. Fig. 3E), or spinal cord thickness (Suppl. Fig. 3F). However, a small decrease in eye size was observed (8 % reduction, Suppl. Fig. 3G) that may be related to compromised photoreceptor maintenance in the absence of Sema4a function (Toyofuku et al, 2012). Similarly, germline mutants (Suppl. Fig. 3H,I) showed an unchanged body length compared to wild type fish (Suppl. Fig. 3J) and also a small reduction in eye diameter (9 % reduction; Suppl. Fig. 3K). Adults were viable and fertile. Hence, gross development of larvae was largely unimpaired in the absence of sema4ab.

To analyse regenerative neurogenesis, we used 5-Ethynyl-2'-deoxyuridine (EdU) labelling in the mnx1:GFP transgenic line that labels motor neurons. Motor neurons represent the main cell type that is newly generated during lesion-induced neurogenesis (Cavone et al., 2021). In unlesioned sema4ab haCR-injected larvae (EdU added at 72 hpf, analysis at 96 hpf) few newly generated motor neurons (EdU+/mnx1:GFP+) were present, similar to control gRNA-injected larvae (Suppl. Fig. 4A-C). This was expected, since sema4ab was not detectable in the spinal cord without lesion and shows that sema4ab does not have a detectable role in ongoing low-level developmental neurogenesis.

After a lesion at 3 dpf, we observed a ~4-fold lesion-induced increase in numbers of new motor neurons in control gRNA-injected larvae at 48 hpl, as previously reported (Ohnmacht et al., 2016). Remarkably, in sema4ab haCR injected larvae, this number was further increased by 85 % compared to lesioned wild type control gRNA-injected larvae (Fig. 3A-C). Similarly, in the lesioned sema4ab germline mutant, the number of new motor neurons almost doubled (95 % increase) compared to lesioned wild type control larvae (Fig. 3D).

For a gain-of-function approach, we generated a construct that leads to overexpression of sema4ab and a fluorescent reporter under the control of a heat-shock promotor (hsp70l:sema4ab-t2a-mCherry, abbreviated as hsp70:sema4ab, Suppl. Fig. 5A). We observed reporter gene expression mainly in muscle cells in heat-shocked lesioned plasmid injected-fish but not in heat-shocked lesioned fish that did not receive plasmid injection (Suppl. Fig. 5B). qRT-PCR in heat-shocked plasmid-injected fish vs heat-shocked controls indicated up to 140 times increased mRNA levels of sema4ab that returned to baseline by 24 hours post-induction (Suppl. Fig. 5C-D).

We used multiple (4 hours before lesion, 20 hpl, 36 hpl) heat-shocks in lesioned animals to ensure sufficient levels of over-expressed sema4ab mRNA. However, we did not observe significant changes in regenerative neurogenesis as determined by the number of EdU+/mnx1:GFP+ cells at 48 hpl (Suppl. Fig. 5E,F). This suggested that the endogenous levels of sema4ab expression already had maximal effects on lesion-induced neurogenesis. In addition, this experiment shows that added Sema4ab protein is not toxic for neurogenesis.

Next, we used the same heat-shock regime on sema4ab germline mutants, in which functional endogenous sema4ab was not present (Fig. 3E). Over-expression completely abolished the increased lesion-induced neurogenesis seen in the mutant (Fig. 3F,G). Given that reporter expression for the overexpressed gene was only detectable in muscle cells, rescuing activity in the spinal cord may be through signalling of soluble Sema4ab from muscle cells. Moreover, this observation confirms that our sema4ab mutant carries a loss-of-function mutation and that Sema4ab controls regenerative neurogenesis.

To determine whether the increased number of new motor neurons observed after sema4ab disruption was a consequence of enhanced progenitor proliferation or neuronal differentiation, we cumulatively labelled ERGs with EdU (Fig. 3H). This indicated a doubling (97% increase) in Edu-labelled ERGs (her4.1:GFP+/EdU+) in sema4ab haCR injected lesioned larvae, compared to control-gRNA injected lesioned larvae (Fig. 3I,J).

To directly show a potential increase in neurogenic differentiation of ERGs, we analysed the expression of the proneural transcription factor neurod1 (Pataskar et al, 2016) by qRT-PCR and HCR-FISH. Lesioned somatic sema4a mutants showed a 60% increase in neurod1 mRNA expression, compared to lesioned control-gRNA injected larvae at 24 hpl in qRT-PCR (Fig. 3K,L), as predicted by scRNAseq (see Fig. 1K). Similarly, the number of neurod1-expressing motor neuron progenitor cells (olig2:EGFP+/neurod1+) was also increased by 50% in lesioned somatic mutants for sema4ab, compared to lesioned control-gRNA injected larvae at 24 hpl (Fig. 3M,N). Hence, in the absence of sema4ab function, the number of EdU label-retaining progenitor cells, the number of neurogenic progenitors, and newly generated neurons were all increased, consistent with sema4ab restricting proliferation of neurogenic progenitors.

sec.title: Disruption of plxnb1a/b augments regenerative neurogenesis
sec.p: scRNAseq predicted direct signalling of microglia to ERGs via Plexin receptors. To find plexin receptor expression in ERGs, we performed HCR-FISH for two plxnb1 (plxnb1a, plxnb1b) and plxn2b (plxnb2a and plxnb2b) paralogs that code for potential Sema4a receptors (Meda et al., 2012; Rajabinejad et al, 2020) in combination with her4.1:EGFP transgenic reporter line, in which ERG progenitor cells are fluorescently labelled under the promoter for her4.1.

Multiplexed HCR-FISH for plxnb1a and plxnb1b in the same larvae showed that plxnb1a mRNA was detectable at low levels in ERGs in unlesioned animals at 3 dpf, with no detectable increase at 24 hpl. The signal for plxnb1b was generally stronger than that for plxnb1a, and also did not show detectable changes after lesion (Fig. 4A-C). High magnifications indicated co-expression of plxnb1a and plxnb1b in the same ERGs (Fig. 4D). Only very low (plxnb1a) or no signal (plxnb1b) was detectable outside ERGs in the spinal cord for both plxnb1a and plxnb1b.

Selective expression of plxnb1a and plxnb1b in ERGs made these good candidates for receiving a sema4ab signal. Therefore, we disrupted plxnb1a and plxnb1b by haCR injection. While single somatic mutations had no effect (Fig. 4E,F), simultaneous mutation of plxnb1a and plxnb1b by co-injecting the respective haCRs increased numbers of newly generated motor neurons (EdU+/mnx1:GFP+) by 55 % at 48 hpl (Fig. 4G).

plxnb2a was only detectable in cells that were located lateral to ERGs in unlesioned and lesioned animals, whereas plxnb2b was expressed in ERGs in unlesioned and lesioned larvae (Suppl. Fig. 6A-D). In the lesion site, signal could be detected that was likely related to non-neuronal cells for both plxnb2a and plxnb2b. However, disrupting plxnb2a and plxnb2b with haCRs had no detectable effect on regenerative neurogenesis (Suppl. Fig. 6E-G). Hence, disrupting plxnb1a/b, which code for Sema4ab receptors and are selectively expressed in ERGs, partially replicated the effect of sema4ab mutation. This suggests direct microglia to ERG interaction via Sema4ab signalling to Plxnb1a/b.

sec.title: Disruption of sema4ab does not induce major changes in numbers and behaviours of invading cell types
sec.p: To characterize the influence of sema4ab on the lesion site environment in situ, we analysed the numbers of cells invading the lesion site with known roles in regeneration, namely neutrophils, BDMs/microglia, and fibroblast-like cells (de Sena-Tomas et al, 2024; Tsarouchas et al., 2018; Tsata et al., 2021; Wehner et al., 2017) (Suppl. Fig. 7A). The number of neutrophils (mpx:GFP+) in the lesion site was unchanged between lesioned control gRNA-injected larvae and sema4ab haCR-injected larvae at 4 hpl (peak of neutrophil invasion) and 24 hpl (peak of regenerative neurogenesis; Suppl. Fig. 7B,C). BDMs/microglia (mpeg:mCherry+) were moderately reduced in number by 12 % in sema4ab haCR injected larvae (Suppl. Fig. 7D) at 24 hpl and the density of fibroblasts (pdgfrb:GFP+) remained unchanged in the absence of sema4ab function (Suppl. Fig. 7E). Hence, numbers of crucial cell types that are recruited to the lesion site remained largely unchanged, confirming data from scRNAseq.

To determine whether BDMs/microglia behaviour was altered in the absence of sema4ab, we analysed phagocytosis of cellular debris, which is one of the major functions of BDMs/microglia (Yu et al, 2022). We used acridine orange staining to detect levels of cellular debris as a proxy for efferocytosis. The average fluorescence intensity of acridine orange in the lesion site was comparable between control gRNA-injected larvae and sema4ab haCR-injected ones at 24 hpl (Suppl. Fig. 7F). Similarly, the number of BDMs/microglia with acridine orange-positive inclusions, as indicators of phagocytosed debris, did not show differences in these experimental groups (Suppl. Fig. 7G). This suggests that efferocytosis of debris by BDMs/microglia was not grossly altered in sema4ab-deficient BDMs/microglia.

sec.title: Cytokine signalling is altered in sema4ab-deficient animals
sec.p: scRNAseq indicated a change in the activation state of sema4ab deficient microglia, which could lead to an altered cytokine milieu in the injury site. Therefore, we analysed expression levels of serum amyloid A (saa), an inflammation marker and regulator of cytokine release (Song et al, 2009), and major pro-(il1b, tnfa, il6, il11b) and anti-(tgfb1a, tgfb3) inflammatory cytokines (Woodcock & Morganti-Kossmann, 2013) in the lesion site environment in control gRNA- and sema4ab haCR-injected lesioned larvae by qRT-PCR at 4 and 24 hpl (Fig. 5A). il1b, tnfa, and il6 did not show any changes at 4 hpl (Fig. 5B), when the immune response was dominated by neutrophils. However, reduced expression levels of il1b (by 50 %), tnfa (by 75 %), and il6 (by 65 %), together with those of il11b (by 45 %) and saa (by 75%), were detected at 24 hpl (Fig. 5C), when microglia dominated the injury site. At that time point, levels of tgfb1a expression were slightly reduced (by 20 %), whereas those of tgfb3 were more than doubled (120 % increase; Fig. 5D). Overall, qRT-PCR results indicate a shift from a pro-inflammatory to an anti-inflammatory lesion environment in the absence of sema4ab function.

To identify possible receptors mediating the effect of Sema4ab on the cytokine environment, we functionally screened additional potential Sema4ab receptors (havcr1, havcr2, nrp1b, plxnd1) using haCR disruption and analysis by qRT-PCR, but none of these replicated the pattern of sema4ab disruption in reducing expression il1b, tnfa, il11b and saa, or increasing expression of tgfb3 (Suppl. Fig. 8A-C). This suggests more complex interactions of sema4ab+ microglia with cells in the lesion site environment.

To track the cellular sources of the changes in cytokine gene expression observed after sema4ab disruption in the lesion site environment, we used transgenic reporter lines and HCR-FISH in histological preparations at 24 hpl (Suppl. Fig. 9A). We found that the number of il1b:GFP double-positive BDMs/microglia (mpeg:mCherry) remained unchanged, but il1b:GFP fluorescence intensity was reduced in sema4ab haCR-injected larvae, compared to control gRNA-injected larvae (Suppl. Fig. 9B). The number of tnfa:EGFP+ BDMs/microglia, as well as fluorescence intensity for tnfa:EGFP was likewise reduced (Suppl. Fig. 9C). In HCR-FISH we found that saa labelling intensity was decreased (Suppl. Fig. 9D). This confirms results from qRT-PCR.

sec.title: Fibroblasts increase tgfb3 expression in the absence of sema4ab function in immune cells
sec.p: In HCR-FISH, the labelling intensity of tgfb3 mRNA was generally increased in sema4ab haCR injected animals compared to control gRNA injected controls, in agreement with qRT-PCR results (Suppl. Fig. 10A,B). Remarkably, expression of tgfb3 in fibroblasts (pdgfrb+), but not in BDMs or microglia (mfap4+) was observed in scRNAseq (Fig. 6A). In agreement with scRNAseq, HCR-FISH co-localisation studies indicated that the tgfb3 signal was not detectable in mfap4:mCherry+ cells. Instead, the signal was present mostly in fibroblasts (pdgfrb:GFP+; Fig. 6B-D and Suppl. Fig. 10C). In contrast, sema4ab was almost exclusively expressed in immune cells (Suppl. Fig. 10D, cf. Fig. 2: Suppl. Fig. 2). Indeed, quantifying the HCR-FISH signal by masking the tgfb3 signal with those for BDMs/microglia and fibroblasts in mfap4:mCherry and pdgfrb:GFP transgenic fish and applying background subtraction (see Material and Methods) indicated that the signal was located in fibroblasts with no detectable signal in BDMs/microglia in either control gRNA- or sema4ab haCR-injected lesioned larvae. Moreover, the HCR-FISH signal was increased by 20 % in the fibroblasts (Fig. 6E,F). This suggests a scenario in which microglia signal to fibroblasts in the lesion site during regeneration. Indeed, live observation of BDMs/microglia (mfap4:mCherry) and fibroblasts (pdgfrb:GFP) from 10 to 25 hpl indicated close physical interactions between these cell types in the injury site, where mfap4:mCherry+ cells move along elongated stationary fibroblasts (Fig. 6G,H and supplemental movies 1 and 2). No obvious differences in these cell behaviours were detectable between control gRNA- and sema4ab haCR-injected larvae. These data suggest that mfap4:mCherry+ cells are in close contact with fibroblasts and may attenuate tgfb3 expression in fibroblasts in the presence of sema4ab.

sec.title: Fibroblasts promote regenerative neurogenesis via Tgfb3
sec.p: Tgfb3 signalling has been implicated in neuronal regeneration in the zebrafish retina before (Lee et al., 2020). To test its role in regenerative neurogenesis in the zebrafish spinal cord, we disrupted tgfb3 genetically in somatic mutants and in a temporally conditional way by pharmacologically blocking Tgfb receptors with the small molecule inhibitor SB431542 (Sun et al, 2006). Animals injected with tgfb3 haCRs showed a 45 % reduction in the number of newly generated motor neurons (EdU+/mnx1:GFP+) after spinal lesion, compared to control gRNA-injected lesioned larvae at 48 hpl (Fig. 7A,B). Similarly, adding SB431542 to the larvae reduced the number of newly generated motor neurons by 45 %, compared to DMSO treated controls, at 48 hpl (Fig. 7C,D). These observations support a promoting role of tgfb3 for regenerative neurogenesis.

sec.title: Disruption of tgfb3 abolishes the effect of sema4ab disruption on lesion-induced neurogenesis
sec.p: To determine whether control of tgfb3 expression by Sema4ab signalling could explain at least in part the role of sema4ab in attenuating regenerative neurogenesis, we disrupted both genes simultaneously by co-injecting sema4ab and tgfb3 haCRs. Disruption of both genes was effective, as indicated by internal RFLP controls for both targets. In these larvae, lesion-induced generation of motor neurons (EdU+/mnx1:GFP+) was indistinguishable from that in lesioned control gRNA-injected larvae (Fig. 7E,F). Hence, disruption of tgfb3 abolished the augmenting effect of sema4ab disruption on regenerative neurogenesis. This suggests that control of tgfb3 expression in fibroblasts is a major mechanism by which sema4ab+ microglia control lesion-induced neurogenesis.

sec.title: Potential sema4ab signalling in adult zebrafish and mouse spinal cord injury
sec.p: To estimate whether the regulation patterns observed here could be conserved across species, we analysed expression of relevant genes in published scRNAseq profiles of the lesioned spinal cord of adult zebrafish (Cigliola et al., 2023) and adult mice (Xue et al, 2024). In adult zebrafish, we found expression of plxnb1a and plxnb1b in clusters of her4.3+ ERGs. We confirmed this by HCR-FISH in cross sections of adult spinal cord, where we found expression in the ventricular layer (Suppl. Fig. 11A-C). In scRNAseq data, sema4ab reads were present in microglia (mfap4+/p2ry12+). tgfb3 reads were present in fibroblasts (pgrfrb+), but not in immune cells (Suppl. Fig. 11A,B). Similarly, in the sample from the lesioned spinal cord of adult mice, we found selective expression of Sema4a in microglia (P2ry12+) and Plxnb1 selectively in potential ventricular progenitors (Foxj1+). Tgfb3 was expressed in fibroblasts (Pdgfra+), but not in microglia (Suppl. Fig. 12A,B). This indicated that in the injured adult zebrafish and mouse spinal cords, microglia, fibroblasts and progenitor cells show comparable selective gene expression to what we observe in larval zebrafish. This is consistent with a potentially conserved role of sema4ab in spinal cord injury across vertebrates.

sec.title: sema4ab disruption enhances axon regrowth and impairs recovery of swimming function
sec.p: We also tested a possible role of sema4ab in other modalities of lesion-induced repair, axon regrowth across a spinal lesion site, and recovery of swimming function. To analyse axon regrowth, we assessed the thickness (cross-sectional area) of the neuronal tissue bridge (tubb5:dsred line) re-connecting the spinal cord stumps (Wehner et al., 2017) (Suppl. Fig. 13A,B). We observed a 59 % increase in bridge thickness at 48 hpl in lesioned sema4ab haCR injected animals, compared to lesioned control gRNA injected animals. This may reflect an inhibitory role of sema4ab on axon growth (Yoneyama et al., 2024).

Functional recovery was assessed by measuring the distance swum after a vibration stimulus. This indicated a 40 % reduction in swim distance in lesioned sema4ab germline mutants, compared to lesioned wild type animals (Suppl. Fig. 13C,D). Uninjured sema4ab germline mutants swam distances that were not different from those of uninjured wild type larvae (Suppl. Fig. 13E,F). These results demonstrate that sema4ab is necessary for recovery of swimming function after injury, but not for development of the locomotor system. This phenotype may be related to the role of Sema4A in synapse formation (McDermott et al, 2018) (see discussion).

In summary, we propose a model by which Sema4ab from microglia controls neurogenesis directly through Plxnb1a/b on ERGs and indirectly via control of fibroblast-derived Tgfb3 in successful spinal cord regeneration in zebrafish (Fig. 7G). Sema4ab has additional functions in axon regeneration and behavioural recovery.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Here we elucidate one of the mechanisms by which regenerative neurogenesis is controlled in a regenerative vertebrate. We show that sema4ab, mainly expressed by microglia, influences several cell types. We provide evidence for major functions of sema4ab in preventing ERG progenitor over-proliferation directly via Plxn1a/b receptors on ERGs and indirectly, by inhibiting Tgfb3 secretion from fibroblasts.

Even though mostly regeneration-promoting signals are reported for regenerating systems, regulation of growth is indispensable for appropriate repair. Here we show that Sema4ab attenuates regenerative neurogenesis. Some other attenuating signals have also been reported. For example, notch signalling is re-activated after spinal injury in adult zebrafish and attenuates neurogenesis there (Dias et al, 2012). In a recent functional screen in the regenerating retina of adult zebrafish, 11 out of 100 regeneration-associated genes have been found to promote and 7 genes to attenuate neuronal regeneration (Emmerich et al, 2024). Interestingly, when a stroke is induced or Notch signalling is disrupted, limited neurogenesis can be elicited from ependymal cells in the lateral ventricles of mice, but this leads to depletion of the ependymal cells (Carlen et al., 2009). Hence, attenuating factors are needed to keep the balance between progenitor maintenance and neuronal differentiation in successful regenerative neurogenesis.

Microglia may signal directly to ERGs to attenuate regenerative neurogenesis. Both signal (sema4ab) and receptors (plxnb1a/b) were expressed with high selectivity in microglia and ERGs, respectively, as indicated by HCR-FISH. However, other cell types may also express low levels of these genes, as suggested by scRNAseq. Direct signalling from BDMs to ERGs has also been shown for Tnfa, but with a promoting effect on neurogenesis (Cavone et al., 2021). In mammals, microglia also attenuate regenerative neurogenesis in the subventricular zone and hippocampus, which is related to its pro-inflammatory status and may in part explain the poor regenerative outcome there (Matsuda et al, 2015; Monje et al, 2003; Nath et al, 2024).

Sema4ab/Plxn1a/b interactions inhibit proliferation of neural progenitor ERGs, but an additional effect on neuronal differentiation cannot be excluded. Interestingly, in mice, mutating PlxnB1 and PlxnB2 together decreased proliferative activity of progenitors and increased their differentiation in the developing cortex, leading to a net effect of reduced neurogenesis (Daviaud et al., 2016). Our re-analysis of mouse scRNAseq data shows that microglia in a spinal injury site in mice selectively express Sema4A and spinal progenitors express Plxnb1. Hence, Sema4A could also contribute to inhibition of neurogenesis in the lesioned spinal cord of mice. A relatively stronger Sema4A signal in mice than in zebrafish could tip the balance to inhibition of neurogenesis after spinal injury.

In addition to potential direct signalling to ERGs, sema4ab also maintains the activation state of microglia. KEGG analysis in microglia clusters highlighted reduced activity of important activation pathways, related to bacterial (Toll-like receptors),viral (RIG-I) response, and initiation of the inflammatory response (Alhamdan et al., 2024; Almeida-da-Silva et al., 2023; Yoneyama et al., 2024) to be changed after disruption of sema4ab. In addition, the top down-regulated genes, including activation markers such as grn1 (Purrahman et al, 2023), confirm this change in activation state. In mammals, microglia cells also express Sema4A (Leitner et al., 2015; Meda et al., 2012), including in a spinal lesion site, as analysed here. In agreement with our findings, injecting exogenous Sema4A into the mouse brain increased activation of microglia there (Chiou et al, 2019). Mammalian macrophages also increase Sema4A expression when activated by lipopolysaccharides (Meda et al., 2012). Since the activation state of microglia affects cytokine signalling (Raziyeva et al, 2021), it was not surprising to detect significant changes in the abundance of different cytokines, in particular a reduction of pro-inflammatory ones, in the absence of sema4ab.

Changes in the cytokine milieu are the likely reason that disruption of sema4ab leads to global changes in the injury site environment. In scRNAseq, we could see profound changes in gene expression in many cell types, however, their abundance in the injury site did not change, as indicated by scRNAseq and histology. Even debris endocytosis by BDMs/microglia appeared unaltered. Hence, scRNAseq analysis reveals complex signalling interactions in a spinal injury site that depend on microglia activation. This data presents a resource for further analysis of the complex lesion site environment.

Combining scRNAseq with HCR-FISH, we here demonstrate that sema4ab signalling regulates expression of tgfb3, a crucial signalling molecule, in fibroblast-like cells. We find tgfb3 expression only in fibroblasts by HCR-FISH and scRNAseq, and sema4ab mostly in microglia. Hence, changes of tgfb3 expression after sema4ab disruption are most likely a consequence of perturbed microglia/fibroblast cross-talk. Interestingly, our re-analysis of mouse scRNAseq data shows expression of Tgfb3 in fibroblasts, but not in microglia, and Sema4A in microglia, but not in fibroblasts in a spinal injury site, raising the possibility for similar microglia/fibroblast cross-talk in a non-regenerating system.

How microglia signal to fibroblasts is unclear. We tried to find evidence for direct involvement of sema4ab signalling. However, somatic mutations of a number of potential receptors for Sema4ab (havcr1, havcr2, nrp1b, plxnd1) (Alto & Terman, 2017; Rajabinejad et al., 2020), could not replicate tgfb3 upregulation or increased neurogenesis (plxnb2a, plxnb2b), or were not detectably expressed by HCR-FISH in non-ERG cells (plxn1a/b). It is most likely that fibroblasts react to changed levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines in the injury site. For example, responsiveness of fibroblasts to pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as TNF (Osei et al, 2020) and IL-1beta (Pilling et al, 2015) is well established and CellChat identified potentially altered tnfb/tnfrsf1a receptor/ligand signalling between microglia and fibroblasts in the absence of Sema4ab signalling.

Our data indicate that fibroblast-produced Tgfb3 promotes regenerative neurogenesis. In the adult zebrafish retina, Tgfb3 has been shown to increase pSmad levels in Müller glia, the retinal progenitor cells, and inhibit their injury-induced proliferation (Lee et al, 2020). However, there is also evidence for pro-regenerative functions of Tgfb3 in zebrafish retina regeneration, perhaps through indirect effects (Conedera et al, 2021; Lenkowski et al, 2013; Sharma et al, 2020). Exogenous TGFB3 has been shown to be a mitogen for retinal cells of the developing rat in vitro (Anchan & Reh, 1995). This indicates context-dependent functions for Tgfb3 in neural development and regeneration.

The altered cytokine environment is also likely to contribute to enhanced axonal regrowth in the absence of sema4ab function. Tgfb3 promotes axon regrowth after spinal cord injury in larval zebrafish (Keatinge et al., 2021) and the increased axon regrowth after sema4ab disruption in our study fits well with the observed increase in tgfb3 expression. Hence, tgfb3 is a pro-regenerative factor after spinal injury, expression levels of which are controlled by sema4ab.

Tgf signalling could act on axon growth via changing the ECM composition. We observed changed expression of ECM-related genes by fibroblasts after sema4ab disruption, as indicated by KEGG analysis. Interestingly, Tgfb3 signalling is associated with scar-free wound healing in mammalian models by modifying ECM composition (Shah et al, 1995; Weng et al, 2020). This may lead to a more favourable spinal ECM environment and could at least in part explain increased axon regeneration in sema4ab somatic mutants (Kolb et al., 2023; Tsata et al., 2021; Wehner et al., 2017). Indeed, depleting BDMs/microglia in spinal cord injury in mammals can lead to a more favourable fibrotic response (Zhu et al, 2015). However, in another model of depleting BDMs, resident microglia were over-activated (Greenhalgh et al, 2018), leading to a worse outcome for recovery. This highlights the complexity of BDMs/microglia cross-talk with fibroblasts and other cell types in potential therapeutic interventions.

The reduced levels of il1b expression seen here may also be promoting axon regrowth. Increased levels of il1b signalling inhibit axon regeneration in an irf8 mutant zebrafish, and direct targeting of il1b expression (Tsarouchas et al., 2018) or reduction by drug treatment (Oprişoreanu et al, 2023) partially rescues axon regrowth in that mutant. This indicates that lower expression levels of il1b may be beneficial for axon growth. On the other hand, we also see reduced expression of tnfa after sema4ab disruption, which does not correlate with the observed increase in axon regrowth. As previously shown, tnfa-deficient larvae show reduced axon regrowth, identifying tnfa as a pro-regenerative factor (Tsarouchas et al., 2018). This again stresses the complexity of signalling cross-talk in a spinal injury site.

It is interesting that the increased axon bridging observed after sema4ab disruption did not translate into improved behavioural recovery. A positive correlation between these read-outs has been observed previously in larval (Tsarouchas et al., 2018; Wehner et al., 2017) and adult (Cigliola et al., 2023; Goldshmit et al., 2012; Huang et al., 2021; Mokalled et al., 2016) lesioned zebrafish. A possible explanation for this apparent discrepancy is that sema4ab may have a role in re-establishing synapses, such that disruption of sema4ab prevents functionally meaningful re-connections. Indeed, the mammalian homolog Sema4A is important for synapse formation (McDermott et al., 2018), as are other Sema4 family members, such as Sema4D (Raissi et al, 2013) and Sema4B (Burkhardt et al, 2005).

We conclude that the microglia activation state is crucial for the outcome of a spinal injury. The balance of pro- and anti-regenerative signals from multiple cell types determines the regenerative outcome. Single cell -omics approaches are well placed to unravel such complexity. Here, we identify microglia-derived sema4ab as a potentially evolutionarily conserved signal in the regulation of the cytokine milieu and as an inhibitor of regeneration of neurons and axons. Hence, Sema4a may present a potential therapeutic target in non-regenerating mammals.

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: All zebrafish lines were raised and kept under standard conditions (Westerfield, 2000). Zebrafish experiments were performed under state of Saxony licenses TVV 36/2021, TVV 45/2018, and holding licenses DD24-5131/364/11, DD24-5131/364/12. For experimental conditions, larvae up to an age of 5 days post-fertilization (dpf) were used of the following lines: wild type (AB); Tg(mnx1:GFP)ml2tg, abbreviated as mnx1:GFP (Flanagan-Steet et al, 2005); Tg(Xla.Tubb:DsRed)zf1826, abbreviated as tubb5:dsred (Peri & Nusslein-Volhard, 2008); Tg(her4.1:EGFP)y83Tg, abbreviated as her4.1:EGFP) (Yeo et al, 2007); Tg(olig2:EGFP), abbreviated as olig2:EGFP (Shin et al, 2003); Tg(mpx:GFP)uwm1, abbreviated as mpx:GFP (Renshaw et al., 2006); Tg(mpeg1.1:mCherry)gl23, abbreviated as mpeg:mCherry (Ellett et al., 2011); Tg(pdgfrb:Gal4ff)ncv24; Tg(UAS:GFP), abbreviated as pdgfrb:GFP (Ando et al, 2016); Tg(il1b:GFP)sh445, abbreviated as il1b:GFP (Nguyen-Chi et al, 2014); and Tg(tnfa:EGFP)ump5Tg, abbreviated as tnfa:EGFP (Nguyen-Chi et al, 2015).

sec.title: Spinal cord lesion
sec.p: Lesions of larvae were performed as previously described (Ohnmacht et al., 2016). Briefly, at 3 dpf, zebrafish larvae were deeply anaesthetized in E3 medium (Nüsslein-Volhard & Dahm, 2002) containing 0,02 % of MS-222 (Sigma). Larvae were then transferred to an agarose plate. After removal of excess water, larvae were placed in lateral positions. A transection of the entire spinal cord was made using a 30G syringe needle at the level of the 15th myotome, without injuring the notochord.

sec.title: Generation of somatic mutants
sec.p: Somatic mutations were generated mainly following a previous protocol (Keatinge et al., 2021). CRISPR gRNAs were selected using the CRISPRscan website (www.crisprscan.org/gene) webtools. gRNAs were chosen based on the CRISPRScan score (preferentially > 60), and on the availability of a suitable restriction enzyme recognition site (www.snapgene.com) that would be destroyed by the gRNA. Additional criteria were to avoid the first exon and to target functional domains. 1 nL of gRNA mix (1 µl of Tracer (5nM, TRACRRNA05N, Sigma-Aldrich), 1 µl of gRNA (20µM, Sigma-Aldrich), 1 µL of phenol red (P0290, Sigma-Aldrich) and 1 µL of Cas9 (20µM, M0386M, New England Biolabs) was injected into one-cell stage embryos. gRNA efficiency was tested by restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis (RFLP) in a proportion of larvae for each experiment as an internal experimental control (Keatinge et al., 2021). Sequences for gRNAs, primers for RFLPs and RFLPs can be found in Suppl. Table 5 and Suppl. Fig. 14. All experiments conducted with somatic mutants were carried out with a control injected group with a non-targeting gRNA.

sec.title: Generation of sema4ab germline mutant and Tg(mfap4:mCherry-CAAX;myl7:mCerulean) line
sec.p: The sema4ab mutant stable line was generated by raising somatic mutants as potential founders, as described (Keatinge et al., 2021). The founder selected to generate the stable line carried a 14 bp insertion in exon 6 that generated a frame shift with a premature stop codon. Sequencing primers were the same as for RFLP.

BDMs/microglia selectively express mfap4 (Walton et al, 2015). To generate the Tg(mfap4:mCherry-CAAX;myl7:mCerulean) line (abbreviated as mfap4:mCherry), pDEST mfap4:turquoise2 vector purchased from Addgene (#135218) was used to PCR-amplify the mfap4 promoter sequence with primers designed to introduce 5´ SacI and 3´ AscI. In parallel, a second plasmid backbone containing ins:nls-mCerulean; cryaa:mCherry (previously generated in the group) was digested with SacI/AscI and ligated with mfap4 using SacI/AscI sites (mfap4:nls-mCerulean; cryaa:mCherry). Subsequently, mCherry was PCR amplified by using primers designed to introduce 5´ EcoRI and 3´ CAAX box followed by a stop codon and PacI. Then mfap4:nls-mCerulean; cryaa:mCherry were digested and ligated using EcoRI/PacI to mCherry-CAAX fragment (mfap4:mCherry-CAAX; cryaa:mCherry). Finally, the newly generated mfap4:mCherry-CAAX; cryaa:mCherry construct and ins1.1:ins-sepHLourin; myl7:NLS-mCerulean construct (previously generated in the lab) were digested with EcoRI/PacI to yield compatible fragments which were ligated together to generate the final construct (mfap4:mCherry-CAAX;myl7:mCerulean).The entire construct was flanked with I-Sce sites to facilitate transgenesis and was injected in wild type AB eggs. Several founders were selected based on mCerulean (blue) expression in the heart and mCherry (red) expression in BDMs and the founder with Mendelian segregation in the F1 was selected. Primers are described in Suppl. Table 6.

sec.title: In situ hybridization chain reaction (HCR-FISH)
sec.p: Larvae were collected in E3 medium and incubated with 0.003 % 1-phenyl 2-thiourea (PTU) at 6 hpf to suppress melanocyte development. Larvae were fixed overnight in 4 % paraformaldehyde (PFA) at 4 ºC and then transferred to 100 % Methanol (MeOH) at -20 °C overnight for permeabilization. The next day, larvae were rehydrated in a graded series of MeOH at room temperature (RT) and subsequent washes in phosphate buffered saline with 0.1 % Tween (PBST). Thereafter, larvae were treated with 500 μL proteinase K (Roche) at a concentration of 30 μg/mL for 45 min at RT, followed by post-fixation in 4 % PFA for 20 min RT and washes with PBST (3 x 5 min). Pre-hybridisation was performed using 500 μL of pre-warmed probe hybridisation buffer (Molecular Instruments (Choi et al., 2018)) for 30 min at 37 °C. The probe sets, which were designed based on the NCBI sequence by Molecular Instruments (Choi et al., 2018), were prepared using 2 pmol of each probe set in 500 μL of pre-warmed hybridisation buffer. Then, buffer was replaced with probe sets and incubated for 16 h at 37 °C. On the following day, samples were washed 4 x 15 min with pre-warmed probe washing buffer (Molecular Instruments) at 37 °C followed by 2 x 5 min in 5x sodium chloride sodium citrate with 0.1 % Tween (SSCT) at RT. Larvae were then treated with 500 μL of room temperature equilibrated amplification buffer (Molecular Instruments, LA, USA) for 30 min at RT. Hairpin RNA preparation was performed following the manufacturer’s instructions. Samples were incubated with Hairpin RNAs for 16 h in the dark at RT. Finally, samples were washed for 3 x 30 min in 5 x SSCT at RT and immersed in 70 % glycerol for imaging on a Zeiss LSM980 confocal microscope.

For HCR-FISH on adult animal, fish were killed, perfusion-fixed with 4% para-formaldehyde, and tissue slices of 50 µm thickness were obtained from dissected unlesioned spinal cord using a vibrating blade microtome (VT1200S, Leica, Wetzlar, Germany), as described (Becker et al, 1997). HCR was performed right away following the protocol described above for larvae, with the exception that no permeabilization steps were applied (starting directly with hybridization blocking buffer step).

sec.title: Combining EdU with motor neuron and ERG labelling
sec.p: Labelling newly generated motor neurons followed previous protocols (Ohnmacht et al., 2016). Briefly, lesioned and unlesioned larvae were incubated in E3 medium containing 1 % dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO, Sigma-Aldrich, Taufkirchen, Germany) and 1:100 EdU (Thermo-Fisher, Schwerte, Germany) for 48 h. Samples were fixed in 4 % PFA for 3h at RT and permeabilised in 100 % MeoH at -20 ºC for at least overnight. Larvae were then rehydrated, tails were dissected and incubated in proteinase K (Roche, Sigma-Aldrich) for 45 min at RT at a concentration of 10 μg/mL and then postfixed at RT in 4 % PFA for 15 min. Then, larvae were incubated for 20 min at RT in 0.5 % DMSO-PBST and incubated for 2 h at RT with the Click-it Chemistry Edu Alexa 647 kit (Thermo-Fisher, Waltham, USA) as described by the manufacturer. Subsequently, tails were washed in PBST and incubated with blocking buffer solution (2 %BSA, 1 % DMSO, 1 % Triton, 10 % Normal donkey serum, in PBST) for 1 h at RT and then with a chicken anti-GFP antibody, (1:200, Abcam, Cambridge, UK) at 4 ºC for 48 hours. Secondary antibody (alexa-488 anti-chicken, 1:200, Jackson Immuno) incubation took place overnight at 4 ºC. Finally, samples were washed in PBST and transferred to 70 % glycerol in PBST, mounted and imaged. Imaging was performed using a Widefield Axio Observer (Inverted) with ApoTome 2 Unit (Zeiss). Images were analysed using Fiji (Rueden et al, 2017; Schindelin et al, 2012). Newly generated motor neurons were counted by assessing the number of double-positive cells for GFP and EdU. Cells were counted manually along the Z-stack, ensuring counting individual cells in single optical sections, in 50 µm windows located at both sides of the injury site (100 µm in total). Experimental conditions were occluded for the analysis. At least two independent experiments were performed. Individual experiments were merged and analysed for statistical significance.

To label proliferating ERGs, we followed the same experimental procedure, imaging and cell counting analysis as for newly generated motor neurons using the ERG reporter line her4.1:EGFP instead of the mnx1:GFP transgenic line.

sec.title: Generation of Heat shock plasmid and treatment
sec.p: To create the pTol:sema4ab-T2a-mcherry plasmid, we modified the pTol-hsp70l:mCherry-T2A-atho1b vector (Ezhkova et al, 2023). We PCR-amplified the sema4ab coding sequence from genomic cDNA and PCR-amplified T2a-mcherry with specific primers (Suppl. Table 7). Then, we performed a simultaneous multiple fragment ligation in the opened backbone vector. The final construct pTol-hsp70l:sema4ab-T2a:mcherry was verified by sequencing, qRT-PCR for over-expression and mCherry fluorescence after injection.

sec.title: Measurement of axonal regrowth
sec.p: As an indicator for successful axon regrowth, we determined the extent of continuous labelling of axons across the spinal cord injury site, termed axonal bridging. As a refinement of previous scoring protocols, we here determined the cross-sectional area of the axonal bridge at its narrowest point. Spinal lesion was performed at 3 dpf as described in larvae that were kept into 0.003 % PTU in E3 water from 72 hpf. The tubb5:dsred transgenic line was chosen for this experiment, because neuronal cell bodies and axons are labelled by fluorescence in that line. At 2 hpl, larvae were inspected under a fluorescence stereo-microscope and those larvae with incomplete spinal cord transection and those in which the notochord was inadvertently injured (over-lesioned) were excluded from the experiment. At 48 hpl, larvae were fixed for 1 h in 4 % PFA and afterwards washed 3 x 5 min with PBST. For microscopy, the larvae were mounted in 70 % glycerol in PBST and imaged right away. Images were taken with a Dragonfly Spinning Disk microscope (Andor/Oxford Instruments, Belfast, UK) with a step size of 1 µm with overall 41 optical sections.

The bridge thickness was determined by calculating the cross-sectional area of the neuronal tissue bridge using a custom script in Fiji (Rueden et al., 2017; Schindelin et al., 2012). Measures were taken at the narrowest point of the axonal bridge, automatically detected by using a maximum projection of the z-stack and a binary segmentation. Measurements of three independent experiments were obtained and merged for statistical analysis (see below and figure legends).

sec.title: Analysis of swimming behaviour
sec.p: The swimming behaviour was assessed using the ZebraBox (View Point, Lyon, France). As above, under- and over-lesioned larvae were excluded from the experiment at 2 hpl. Subsequently, the larvae were individually arranged in 24-well plates, ensuring representation of all groups on each plate, and kept in the incubator at 28 ºC until 48 hpl. Larval movements were automatically tracked during three repetitions of the same protocol. The protocol comprised 1 min of rest, a 1 second vibration stimulus (frequency set at 1000 Hz [target power 100]), followed by 59 seconds of no stimulus. The analysis focused on the time-period of 1 minute encompassing the vibration stimulus (including the 1-second stimulus and the subsequent 59 seconds). For each larva, the mean of their swimming distances over the three repeats was computed. Two independent experiments with an average of 30 larvae per condition were performed and the results were merged for statistical analysis (see below and figure legends).

sec.title: Quantitative RT-PCR
sec.p: Following spinal cord lesion of 3 dpf, RNA extraction was performed at 1 dpl using the RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) according to the manufacturer's instructions (50 larvae/condition). The injury site was enriched by cutting away rostral and caudal parts from the larvae at positions approximately 3 somites away from the lesion site in either direction. cDNA was synthesized using the iScript™ cDNA Synthesis Kit (BioRad, cat #. 1708890) according to the manufacturer's instructions. qRT-PCR was performed using the SsoAdvanced Universal SYBR Green Supermix kit (BioRad) according to the manufacturer's instructions and run in triplicates on a LightCycler 480SW instrument (Roche). For gene-specific primers see Suppl. Table 8. Each condition was normalized to a housekeeping gene and the experimental group was compared to controls by normalizing to the control group. At least three individual experiments were run. For statistical analysis, a One-Sample T-test was used.

sec.title: Immune cell counting in whole-mounted larvae
sec.p: Larvae were lesioned at 3 dpf and fixed for 1 h in 4 % PFA at different time points. Larvae were washed in PBST and transferred to glycerol (70 % in PBST), mounted and imaged immediately using a Widefield Axio Observer (Inverted) with an ApoTome 2 Unit. Images were analysed using Fiji with the experimental condition unknown to the observer. A window of 200 µm width and 75 µm height was placed in the centre of the injury site of individual images, right above the notochord. Cells were counted manually inside the window along the Z-stack with the experimental condition occluded. At least two individual experiments were carried out and merged.

sec.title: Acridine Orange labelling
sec.p: Larvae of the mpeg:mCherry line were incubated after a lesion in 1 µg/ml of Acridine Orange (stock solution 10 mg/ml in water) in E3 for 24 h. Then, fish were washed for 3 x 10 min in E3. Larvae were then mounted in 0.5 % agarose in E3 for live imaging on the Dragonfly Spinning Disk microscope (Andor). To estimate total debris, GFP mean intensity was analysed using a 250x100 µm counting window placed in the centre of the injury site. To determine the number of BDMs/microglia that ingested debris, cells positive for both mCherry and GFP were counted in the injury site using same window as before.

sec.title: Fluorescence intensity/area measurements
sec.p: Images were analysed with Fiji ImageJ (https://imagej.net/ij/). The region of interest was defined as a rectangle of 400 x 100 µm, centred on the injury site and located right above the notochord. Z-stacks were collapsed in sum intensity projections and then background subtraction was performed before analysing the mean intensity with a custom Fiji macro to automatize the process (Rueden et al., 2017; Schindelin et al., 2012). Mean intensity was represented by normalizing each value to the control average value.

sec.title: Drug treatment of larvae
sec.p: SB431542 (Fisher Scientific) was dissolved in DMSO to a stock concentration of 10 mM. The working concentration was 50 µM prepared by a dilution of the stock solution in E3. Larvae were pre-treated for 2 h before injury and then incubated for 48 hpl. Control larvae were treated with DMSO at the same concentration.

sec.title: Cell dissociation and fluorescence-activated sorting
sec.p: 50 larvae per sample were used. Lesion-site tissue was neriched by dissecting 3 somites rostral and caudal of the injury site and collecting them in cold 1 x PBS. The tissue was dissociated using the Miltenyi Neural Tissue Dissociation Kit (P) with addition of collagenase. In brief, we removed excess 1x PBS and added 950 µL Buffer X. 6 µL of 1/1000 diluted β-mercaptoethanol, 50 µL Enzyme P and 8 µL collagenase (50 mg/mL) were added. The tissue was pipetted 10 times with 1 mL pipette tips and let it rotate at RT (~22-23 °C) for approximately 1 min. In the meantime, 10 µL of Buffer Y and 10 µL of Enzyme A were mixed and added this to the dissociation mix. Tissue was triturated slowly using fire polished small-orifice glass Pasteur pipette. Each trituration was performed 10 times (6 seconds each) for 1 min and we let the sample rotate for 1 min. This step was repeaed until complete dissociation was achieved. The reaction was stopped after ~14 mins by adding 1 mL of DMEM + FBS (1 %) + Protease Inhibitor (1 x) mix (DFP), followed by centrifugation at + 4 °C at 500 g for 5 mins. The supernatant was removed and the pellet was resuspended in 1 mL of HBSS (Mg2+/Ca+) + Protease Inhibitor (1x) and then passed through a 40 µm filter equilibrated with 200 µL of DFP. Cells were recentrifuged at +4 °C at 500 g for 5 mins. The pellet was resuspended in 300 µL of DFP. Just before cell sorting, 0.5 µL of propidium iodide (100 µg/mL) was added and mixed well by pipetting. Viable, propidium iodide-negative cells were sorted using FACS Aria (BD Biosciences) using a 100 µm nozzle at flow rate 1. 100,000 cells per sample were sorted into BSA coated 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes with 500 µL of a 0.4 % BSA solution in 1x PBS. The sorted cells volume was around 200 µL and the final concentration of BSA was 0.28 %. One control gRNA and two sema4ab gRNA samples were processed by the Dresden Concept Genome Center for cell encapsulation using the 10X Genomic V3.

sec.title: Droplet encapsulation and single-cell RNA sequencing
sec.p: Cells were pelleted at 500 g for 5 minutes at 4°C, leaving 20 µL of suspension. Cell viability was assessed with trypan blue, and samples with > 80 % viability were prepared for encapsulation. Single-cell RNA sequencing followed the 10x Genomics (Chromium Single-cell Next GEM 3’ Library Kit V3.1) workflow (Zheng et al, 2017). In brief, cells were mixed with Reverse Transcription Reagent and loaded onto a Chromium Single Cell G Chip, targeting 10,000 cells per sample. GEM generation, barcoding, reverse transcription, cDNA amplification, fragmentation, and purification were performed according to the manufacturer’s protocol. Libraries were prepared using 25 % of cDNA, quantified, and sequenced on an Illumina NovaSeq 6000 in 100 bp paired-end mode.

sec.title: Alignment to zebrafish genome
sec.p: The raw sequencing data were processed with the ‘count’ command of the Cell Ranger software (v7.1) provided by 10x Genomics. To build the reference, the zebrafish genome (GRCz11) and gene annotation (Ensembl 109), were downloaded from Ensembl (https://www.ensembl.org/). The ‘count’ command was used to generate count matrices that were further used by Seurat V5 for downstream analyses.

sec.title: Quality Control and Doublet Removal
sec.p: For data analyses, cells were kept based on the following conditions: (i) nFeature_RNA >= 200 (number of genes detected per cell), 500 < nCount_RNA < 50000 (number of total reads detected per cell), (ii) percent.mt > 20 % (mitochondrial RNA percentage), (iii) nCount_RNA/nFeature_RNA > 20-fold (an indication of possible doublets), (iv) genes found in fewer than 3 cells were removed from the analyses. Additionally, doublets were determined using scDblFinder V1.18.0 (Germain et al, 2021). However, rare cells expressing markers for cell types distinct from the clusters they were allocated to remained and were possible doublets. Cells were removed, if cells other than neurons expressed elavl3 or elavl4, if cells other than red blood cells expressed hbbe1.3/hbbe2, if cells other than muscle, fibroblast-like cells or keratinocytes expressed col12a1a, col12a1b, or if cells other than muscle or fibroblast-like cells expressed fgl1, or vwde. Using this method an additional ~5% of cells per sample were removed.

sec.title: Seurat Data Analyses
sec.p: After filtering out low-quality cells and doublets, we utilized Seurat V5 for data integration using the CCAIntegration method, following the standard pipeline. A Seurat object was created, and the data were normalized. The top 2,000 variable genes were identified, and the data were scaled using all genes, with nCount_RNA regressed out. Clustering was performed at a resolution of 1.0, yielding 44 distinct clusters (0–43).

After removing low-quality cells and doublets, we utilized Seurat V5 for data integration using CCAIntegration method and followed its standard pipeline. Briefly, a Seurat object was created and the data were normalized. The top 2000 variable genes were identified, and the data were scaled using all genes, with nCount_RNA regressed out. Clustering was performed at resolution 1, yielding 44 distinct clusters (numbered as 0-43).

sec.title: Finding Marker Genes and annotation of clusters
sec.p: To identify marker genes (the genes which are specific to a cluster compared to the remaining all other cell types), the FindAllMarkers function from Seurat, using the default options was used. The “Wilcoxon rank sum test”, and p_val_adj (p-value adjusted) < 0.1 and avg_log2FC >= 0.25 (average log2 fold change) was used for selecting significantly expressed marker genes. Additionally, genes were selected using pct.1 (percentage in the cluster) > 0.2 and ordered, based on their agvg_log2FC in descending order for each cell cluster. Based on the literature, known cell type marker genes were selected from the top ranked genes and used to annotate the main cell types accordingly.

The main cell types were annotated using the following marker genes and the top-ranked genes for each cluster (Cavone et al., 2021; Chen et al, 2023; Farrell et al, 2018): Ependymoradial Glia (ERG; fabp7a, sox2), Enteric Nervous System (ENS; phox2aa, phox2b), Fibroblast-Like Cells (FBL; 3 main clusters, col12a1a, col12a1b, pdgfrb+), Keratinocytes (KC; pfn1, krt4), Peridermis (PD; krt5, krt91, icn2), Muscle Cells (MC; meox1, mylz3), Xanthophores (XP; gch2, aox5), Oligodendrocyte (OD; cldnk, mbpb, mpz), Kolmer-Agduhr Cells (KA; npcc, sst1.1), neutrophils (NP; lcp1, mpx, lyz), BDMs/microglia (MM; lcp1, mfap4, mpeg1.1), Neurons (NN; elavl3, elavl4), Endothelia Cells (EC; kdrl, cldn5b), Notochord (NC; shha, gas2b), Red Blood Cells (RBC; hbbe1.3, hbbe2) and 5 clusters that remained not annotated (c#28, c#31, c#32, c#34 and c#36).

sec.title: Differentially Expressed Gene Analysis (DEG)
sec.p: The FindMarkers function in Seurat was used to determine the differentially expressed genes using “Wilcoxon rank sum test”. p_val_adj < 0.1 and abs(avg log2FC) >= 0.25 were used for selecting significantly expressed genes.

sec.title: Gene Ontology term and KEGG Analyses
sec.p: For KEGG (Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes) analyses, GOstats (Falcon & Gentleman, 2007), giving all differentially expressed genes (over- or under-represented) using 0.25 log2FC and p_value < 0.05 as input, were used. Enriched terms were selected with a p-value < 0.05.

sec.title: Cell-Cell Interaction
sec.p: CellChat V2.1.0 (Jin et al., 2021) was used for cell-cell interaction and a custom cell-cell interaction as described (Cosacak et al. 2019). In brief, the CellChat Database was modified by adding sema4ab as ligand and plxnb1a, plxnb1b, plxnb2a, plxnb2b, plxnd1, havcr1, havcr2, nrp1a and nrp1b as its receptors. As there was a pathway named SEMA4, the pathway was renamed to “SEMA4AB” for sema4ab and to “SEMA4other” for sema4c/sema4g. Then, CellChat objects were created for each data set using normalized data from the integrated Seurat object. Finally, the CellChat objects were merged for comparative analyses.

sec.title: Cell cycle scoring analysis (for materials and methods)
sec.p: Cell cycle scoring analysis was performed using the “Cell-Cycling Scoring and Regression” code for Seurat in R (Satija et al., 2015) (https://github.com/satijalab/seurat/blob/HEAD/vignettes/cell_cycle_vignette.Rmd; compiled: 2023-10-31) based in a published gene list (Tirosh et al, 2016) (loaded in Seurat) and adapted to zebrafish orthologues manually using ZFIN (Sprague et al, 2003).

sec.title: Time-lapse microscopy
sec.p: Zebrafish larvae were prepared for time lapse microscopy based on our established protocol (https://ibidi.com/img/cms/support/UP/UP12_Zebrafish_Co_Culture.pdf). Briefly, double transgenic zebrafish larvae (pdgfrb:GFP; mfap4:mCherry) were lesioned at 3 dpf and anaesthetized with MS-222 (160 mg/L in E3 medium). Low melting point agarose (0.5 %, Biozym Plaque Agarose - Low melting Agarose #840100) was prepared in E3 medium and allowed to cool down to 38 °C before adding MS-222 (final concentration 80 mg/L). Anaesthetized zebrafish larvae were transferred to the agarose and one by one positioned into individual wells of the chambered coverslip. Six larvae were used in total; three control gRNA-injected and three sema4ab haCR-injected ones. Microscopy was performed with a Dragonfly Spinning Disk microscope (Andor/Oxford Instruments, Belfast, UK) with a temperature-controlled stage at 28 °C using a 20x objective (20x/0.75 U Plan SApo, Air, DIC, OLYMPUS, Tokyo, Japan). The GFP fluorophore was excited with a 488 nm laser (laser power 20 %) with an exposure time of 180 ms and the mCherry flourophore was excited with a 561 nm laser (laser power 50 %) with an exposure time of 900 ms. We acquired z-stacks of 43 optical sections, with a step size of 1 µm. The interval between single frames of the time-lapse movies was 6 minutes. Time-lapse was performed from 10 hpl until 25 hpl.

sec.title: Bias mitigation and statistical analysis
sec.p: The experimental conditions were occluded before manual counting and analysis and processing was automated where possible (e. g. measurements of axonal regrowth and intensity measurements). For manual counts of EdU+ cells, pilot experiments were performed by two independent experimenters, both showing comparable effect sizes. Experiments were performed in duplicate, if not indicated differently.

Statistical methods to analyse scRNAseq data are described above. For all other experiments, quantitative data was tested for normality using Shapiro-Wilk’s W-test. Then, parametric (unpaired Student’s t-test or one-way ANOVA) and non-parametric (Mann-Whitney U test or Kruskal-Wallis test) were applied as appropriate. Error bars in figures indicate standard error of the mean (SEM), p-values were represented as asterisks in the figures (*p < 0.05; **p < 0.01; *** p < 0.001) and exact p-values are given in figure legends. To generate graphs and for statistical analysis we used GraphPad Prism 8 (GraphPad Software, Boston, USA).

sec.title: Figure preparation
sec.p: Images were adjusted for brightness, contrast and intensity. Drawings were made using CorelDraw X8 (Corel/Alludo, Ottawa, Canada). Figure plates were prepared using CorelDraw X8 (Corel/Alludo, Ottawa, Canada) and Adobe Photoshop 2024 (Adobe, CA, USA).

Drug treatment using the small molecule inhibitor SB431542 against Tgfb-receptors mimics reduction in regenerative neurogenesis observed with tgfb3 somatic mutants (D, DMSO: 10.8 cells per larva ± 1.15; SB431542: 5.9 cells per larva ± 0.63; p = 0.0011). (E,F) A schematic timeline for double gene disruption is shown (F). Double haCR injection against sema4ab and tgfb3 restores control levels of regenerative neurogenesis (gControl: 8.1 cells per larva ± 0.7; gSema4ab+gTgfb3: 6.6 cells per larva ± 0.8; p = 0.1523). (G) A graphical summary of proposed interactions of sema4ab during spinal cord regeneration is shown. After spinal injury, microglia likely control neurogenesis directly by signalling through Sema4ab and Plxnb1a/b on ERGs and indirectly by controlling expression of tgfb3, a positive regulator of regenerative neurogenesis, in fibroblasts.
